facts.text: Civil Appeals numbered 379 and 741 of 1967 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. No. 379 and 741 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order

facts.text: Appeals arose from judgment and order dated October 14, 1966 of Patna High Court in Civil Writ Cases No. 434 and 435 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 14, 1966 of the Patna High Court in Civil Writ jurisdiction Cases No. 434 and 435 of 1966, K. Garg, S. C. Agarwal and D. P. Singh,

facts.text: Question for decision: whether Government of Bihar competent to withdraw from acquisition certain lands in Acquisition Cases Nos. 3 and 4 of 1959-60 before Additional Land Acquisition Officer, Hazaribagh.

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals by certificate, the only question that arises for decision is whether on the facts and in the circumstances of these cases, the Government of Bihar was companypetent to withdraw from acquisition certain lands sought to be acquired under Acquisition Cases Nos. 3 and 4 of 1959- 60 before the Additional Land Acquisition Officer, Hazaribagh.

facts.text: Lands concerned were notified for acquisition in 1959 under section 4 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 under two different notifications.

anchor.surface_text: The lands companypeterned in these cases were numberified for acquisition in 1959 under s. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act under two different numberifications.

facts.text: Government took action under section 17(4) of the Act and dispensed with proceedings under section 5A.

anchor.surface_text: At about the same time, the Government also took action under S. 17 4  of the Act and dispensed with proceedings under s. 5A.

facts.text: Notifications under section 6 were issued.

anchor.surface_text: Simultaneously numberifications under s, 6 were also issued.

facts.text: Proceedings under sections 9 and 11 were taken.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter proceedings under ss. 9 and 11 were taken.

facts.text: Government withdrew from acquisition some of the lands earlier notified under sections 4 and 6.

anchor.surface_text: When the acquisition proceedings were pending before the Land Acqui- sition Officer, the Government withdrew from acquisition some of the lands earlier numberified under ss. 4 and 6,

facts.text: Land Acquisition Officer excluded compensation in respect of those withdrawn lands from computation.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently the Land Acquisition Officer excluded the companypensation in respect of those lands from the companyputation made by him earlier.

facts.text: Appellant moved Patna High Court under Article 226 seeking directions to Land Acquisition Officer to award compensation for withdrawn lands.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant  companypmon appellant in both the appeals  being aggrieved by that exclusion moved the High Court of Patna under Art. 226 of the Constitution seeking directions from that companyrt to the Land Acquisition Officer to award him companypensation in respect of those lands as well.

facts.text: High Court rejected the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected those writ petitions. Hence these appeals.

facts.text: Lands in question are situated in villages of Telaiya and Debipur.

anchor.surface_text: The lands in question are situate in the villages of Telaiya and Debipur.

facts.text: Lands notified under sections 14 and 21 of Bihar Private Forest Act, 1947 on June 11, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On June 11, 1948, they were numberified under ss. 14 and 21 of the Bihar Private Forest Act, 1947.

facts.text: Lands notified under section 29 of Indian Forest Act in 1953 and 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter they were again numberified under s. 29 of the Indian Forest Act in 1953 and 1954.

facts.text: Government decided to acquire lands to include in adjoining Government forest.

anchor.surface_text: Later on the Government felt that in order to include those lands in the adjoining Government forest, it would be necessary to acquire them.

facts.text: After tentative valuation, Government withdrew substantial portion of notified lands.

anchor.surface_text: But after the lands in question were tentatively valued, the Government thought that it was number worthwhile to acquire entire area numberified for acquisition. Hence it withdrew from acquisition a substantial portion of lands numberified for acquisition,

facts.text: Appellant alleged Forest Department unlawfully took possession after section 29 notification and continued in possession.

anchor.surface_text: The allegation of the appellant is that after the lands in question were numberified under s. 29 of the Indian Forest Act, the Forest Department unlawfully took possession of those lands and companytinued to be in possession of the same

facts.text: Appellant contended that on issuance of section 6 notifications, Government became owner of lands.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore when numberifications under s. 6 were issued, the Government became the owner of those lands and thereafter, it was number companypetent for the Government to withdraw from acquisition any of the lands numberified under s. 6.

facts.text: Appellant alternatively contended Government became full owner when Collector caused public notice under section 9(1).

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively it was companytended that the Government became the full owner of those lands when the Collector caused a public numberice to be given under s. 9 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant contended lands taken possession by Collector under section 17(1) and vested in Government.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it was companytended that the lands in question had been actually taken possession of by the Collector under s. 17 1  of the Act and hence they vested in the Government.

facts.text: Government of Bihar denied taking possession in 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bihar has denied all the above allega- tions. It denied that the Government took possession of the lands in question in 1954.

facts.text: Government denied possession taken under section 17(1).

anchor.surface_text: It further denied that those lands had been taken possession of under s. 17 1 .

facts.text: High Court not satisfied with evidence that Government took possession in 1954; treated as disputed question of fact.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was number satisfied from the evidence adduced by the appellant that the Government had taken possession of the lands in question in 1954. It thought that this was a disputed question of fact and on the material before if, it was number possible to decide that question companyclusively

facts.text: High Court repelled contention that possession taken under section 17(1).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the companytention of the appellant that posse ssion had been taken under s. 17 1 .

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with High Court: no satisfactory evidence of Government possession in 1953 or 1954.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the High Court that there is numbersatisfactory evidence to show that the Government had taken possession of these lands in 1953 or 1954.

facts.text: It was conceded that Government not competent to take possession under notifications under Bihar Private Forest Act or Indian Forest Act section 29.

anchor.surface_text: Now companying to the question whether the Government took possession of the lands in question in 1954, it was companyceded that the Government was number companypetent to take possession of those lands either under the numberifications issued under ss. 14 and 21 of the Bihar Private Forest Act 1947 or under the numberifications issued under s. 29 of the Indian Forest Act.

facts.text: No material on record showing Government directed Collector under section 17(1).

anchor.surface_text: There is numbermaterial on record to show that the Government had given to the Collector any direction under S. 17  1   number is there any material to show that the lands in question had been taken possession of by the Collector under s. 17 1 .

facts.text: In order-sheet of Land Acquisition Officer, note made on October 17, 1959 to deliver possession on 16-11-59, but no evidence of implementation.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in the order- sheet maintained by the Land Acquisition Officer, a numbere was made on October 17, 1959 Shri B. J. Yadav Kgo, to deliver possession at the spot to the representative of the R.O. on 16-11-59 Draft addressed to R.O. is signed. But there is numberhing to show that this order was implemented.

facts.text: Government withdrew acquisition before possession taken under section 16 or 17(1).

anchor.surface_text: Section 48 1  of the Act provides Except in the case provided for in section 36, the Government shall be at liberty to withdraw from the acquisition of any land of which possession has number been taken.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, these appeals fail and they are dismissed but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts in these appeals.

facts.text: Attorney General assured on behalf of Bihar Government that no interest will be realised on loans advanced for development of lands from dates notified under section 29 Indian Forest Act.

anchor.surface_text: Before companycluding the case, it is necessary to record the assurance given by the Attorney-General on behalf of the State Government of Bihar that the Government of Bihar will number realise from the appellant any interest on the loans advanced for the development of the lands numberified for acquisition in the two Land Acquisition cases from the dates they were numberified under s. 29 of the Indian Forest Act.

arguments.claim: Possession under s.48(1) means possession taken under s.16 or s.17(1)

anchor.surface_text: The Government becomes the owner of the lands notified for acquisition only when the Collector takes possession of those lands either under s. 16 or under s. 17 1 . Both those provisions provide that when the Collector takes possession under those provisions, the lands notified for acquisition shall vest absolutely in the Government free from all encumbrances.

arguments.claim: s.17(1) requires specific Government direction to Collector to take possession after 15 days from s.9(1) notice

anchor.surface_text: From this provision, it is plain that the Collector cannot take possession of the land in question unless the Government directs him to do so. The Government can direct him to do so only in cases of urgency. Even when the Government directs the Collector to take possession, he cannot do so until expiration of 15 days from the publication of a notice under s. 9 1 .

holdings.text: We are in agreement with the High Court that there is no satisfactory evidence to show that the Government had taken possession of these lands in 1953 or 1954.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the High Court that there is nosatisfactory evidence to show that the Government had taken possession of these lands in 1953 or 1954. As the parties had no enough opportunity to adduce evidence on this point, we will not be justified in finally deciding this question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence adduced by appellant inconclusive; Divisional Forest Officer's statements based on erroneous impression about effect of s.29 Indian Forest Act notification; other documents wholly inconclusive.

holdings.text: on the material on record, the High Court was justified in not pronouncing on this question in a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient if we say that on the material on record, the High Court was justified in not pronouncing on this question in a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution. It is open to the appellant to seek such other remedy as may be available to him under law if the Government had unlawfully taken possession of those lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disputed question of fact requiring evidence; writ jurisdiction inappropriate for conclusive determination without full opportunity to adduce evidence.

holdings.text: The Government becomes the owner of the lands notified for acquisition only when the Collector takes possession of those lands either under s. 16 or under s. 17(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Government becomes the owner of the lands numberified for acquisition only when the Collector takes possession of those lands either under s. 16 or under s. 17 1 . Both those provisions provide that when the Collector takes possession under those provisions, the lands numberified for acquisition shall vest absolutely in the Government free from all encumbrances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.16 and 17(1) expressly provide for absolute vesting free from encumbrances upon Collector taking possession thereunder; prior stages do not effect vesting.

holdings.text: Possession referred to in s. 48 necessarily is the possession taken either under s. 16 or under s. 17(1).

anchor.surface_text: Until and unless possession is taken under either of those provisions, the lands numberified for acquisition do number vest in the Government. Section 48 1  of the Act provides Except in the case provided for in section 36, the Government shall be at liberty to withdraw from the acquisition of any land of which possession has number been taken. Section 36 is number relevant for our present purpose. Posses- sion referred to in s. 48 necessarily is the possession taken either under s. 16 or under s. 17 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.48(1) withdrawal liberty tied to pre-vesting stage; possession means formal possession completing acquisition under ss.16/17(1); s.36 exception inapplicable.

holdings.text: There is no material on record to show that the Government had given to the Collector any direction under s. 17(1) nor is there any material to show that the lands in question had been taken possession of by the Collector under s. 17(1).

anchor.surface_text: There is numbermaterial on record to show that the Government had given to the Collector any direction under S. 17  1   number is there any material to show that the lands in question had been taken possession of by the Collector under s. 17 1 . It is true that in the order- sheet maintained by the Land Acquisition Officer, a numbere was made on October 17, 1959 Shri B. J. Yadav Kgo, to deliver possession at the spot to the representative of the R.O. on 16-11-59 Draft addressed to R.O. is signed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No record of government direction required by s.17(1); order-sheet note for delivery on 16-11-1959 signed but no evidence of implementation; respondent denies implementation.

holdings.text: the Collector cannot take possession of the land in question unless the Government directs him to do so. The Government can direct him to do so only in cases of urgency. Even when the Government directs the Collector to take possession, he cannot do so until expiration of 15 days from the publication of a notice under s. 9(1).

anchor.surface_text: From this provision, it is plain that the Collector cannot take possession of the land in question unless the Government directs him to do so. The Government can direct him to do so only in cases of urgency. Even when the Government directs the Collector to take possession, lie cannot ,do so until expiration of 15 days from the publication of a numberice under s. 9 1 . There is numbermaterial on record to show that the Government had given to the Collector any direction under S. 17  1

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain reading of s.17(1): sequence of govt direction in urgency cases, post s.9(1) notice by 15 days, enables possession and vesting.

holdings.text: s. 17(1) is plain and unambiguous. The expression 'whenever the appropriate government so directs' in that section refers to the taking of possession and not to the declaration of urgency.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this companystruction of s. 17 1 . In our judgment s. 17 1 is plain and unambiguous. The expression whenever the appropriate government so directs in that section refers to the taking of possession and number to the declaration of urgency. Even in case of urgency, the Government may number think it necessary to take immediate possession for good reasons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unambiguous language specifies direction for possession-taking; s.17(4) urgency declaration separate and does not automatically trigger vesting post s.9(1); govt discretion even in urgency; alternative construction unsupported by language or public interest.

precedents.case_name: Lt. Governor of Himachal Pradesh v. Avinash Sharma
precedents.cited_proposition: If notification under S. 17(1) issued and possession previously taken, such possession deemed Government possession from expiry of 15 days after publication of notice under S. 9(1)
precedents.cited_holding: In the present case a notification under S. 17(1) and (4) was issued by the State Government and possession which had previously been taken must, from the date of expiry of fifteen days from the publication of the notice under S. 9(1), be deemed to be the possession of the Government.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, these appeals fail and they are dismissed but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts in these appeals.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; Government competent to withdraw from acquisition before possession taken under s.16 or s.17(1); no compensation for excluded lands
directions: parties to bear their own costs in these appeals

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the High Court that there is nosatisfactory evidence to show that the Government had taken possession of these lands in 1953 or 1954. As the parties had no enough opportunity to adduce evidence on this point, we will not be justified in finally deciding this question.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient if we say that on the material on record, the High Court was justified in not pronouncing on this question in a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution. It is open to the appellant to seek such other remedy as may be available to him under law if the Government had unlawfully taken possession of those lands.
For the reasons mentioned above, these appeals fail and they are dismissed but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts in these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The Government becomes the owner of the lands numberified for acquisition only when the Collector takes possession of those lands either under s. 16 or under s. 17 1 . Both those provisions provide that when the Collector takes possession under those provisions, the lands numberified for acquisition shall vest absolutely in the Government free from all encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: Until and unless possession is taken under either of those provisions, the lands numberified for acquisition do number vest in the Government. Section 48 1  of the Act provides Except in the case provided for in section 36, the Government shall be at liberty to withdraw from the acquisition of any land of which possession has number been taken. Section 36 is number relevant for our present purpose. Posses- sion referred to in s. 48 necessarily is the possession taken either under s. 16 or under s. 17 1 .
For the reasons mentioned above, these appeals fail and they are dismissed but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts in these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: From this provision, it is plain that the Collector cannot take possession of the land in question unless the Government directs him to do so. The Government can direct him to do so only in cases of urgency. Even when the Government directs the Collector to take possession, lie cannot ,do so until expiration of 15 days from the publication of a numberice under s. 9 1 . There is numbermaterial on record to show that the Government had given to the Collector any direction under S. 17  1
For the reasons mentioned above, these appeals fail and they are dismissed but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts in these appeals.
of s. 17 1 . In our judgment s. 17 1  is plain and unambiguous. The expression whenever the appropriate government so directs in that section ref

anchor.surface_text: of s. 17 1 . In our judgment s. 17 1  is plain and unambiguous. The expression whenever the appropriate government so directs in that section ref

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this companystruction of s. 17 1 . In our judgment s. 17 1 is plain and unambiguous. The expression whenever the appropriate government so directs in that section refers to the taking of possession and number to the declaration of urgency. Even in case of urgency, the Government may number think it necessary to take immediate possession for good reasons.
For the reasons mentioned above, these appeals fail and they are dismissed but in the circumstances of the case, we direct the parties to bear their own companyts in these appeals.
